name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)
summary: A specialized form of CBT designed to treat chronic insomnia by addressing maladaptive sleep habits, dysfunctional beliefs, and behavioral patterns that interfere with restful sleep.
description: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line, evidence-based treatment for chronic insomnia. Unlike general CBT, CBT-I is tailored specifically to sleep difficulties and includes strategies such as stimulus control, sleep restriction therapy, relaxation training, and cognitive restructuring. CBT-I has been shown to be as effective as, or more effective than, pharmacological sleep aids in the long term, with sustained benefits after treatment completion. It is effective across populations, including older adults, individuals with comorbid depression or anxiety, and those with chronic medical conditions.

conditions_treated: Insomnia associated with chronic medical illness
off_label_uses: Adjunct to tapering off hypnotic medications
contraindications: Severe untreated psychiatric conditions (psychosis, acute mania)
Inability to adhere to structured sleep protocols
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and well-tolerated; some patients may experience transient fatigue or daytime sleepiness when initiating sleep restriction therapy.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong—endorsed by the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) and recommended as first-line treatment by NIH and APA.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple meta-analyses confirm CBT-I as the gold-standard for insomnia, superior to medication in long-term outcomes.

sections.text: CBT-I works by breaking the cycle of conditioned arousal and maladaptive sleep habits. Cognitive techniques target dysfunctional beliefs about sleep (e.g., catastrophizing the effects of poor sleep), while behavioral strategies—such as stimulus control and sleep restriction—realign sleep-wake patterns and strengthen the bed as a cue for sleep. Relaxation and mindfulness-based approaches reduce physiological arousal that interferes with sleep onset and maintenance.

sections.preparation: Initial sleep history and 1–2 week sleep diary to assess patterns.
procedure: Psychoeducation about sleep regulation and sleep hygiene.
Stimulus control therapy (restricting bed to sleep and intimacy only).
Sleep restriction therapy (limiting time in bed to consolidate sleep).
Cognitive restructuring of maladaptive sleep beliefs.

sections.pre_session: Review sleep diary and adherence to behavioral prescriptions.
sections.treatment_phase: Introduce and practice one or more techniques (e.g., stimulus control, cognitive restructuring).
sections.post_session: Assign updated sleep prescriptions and strategies for the week.

rare: Increased anxiety when eliminating safety behaviors around sleep

relative: Shift workers with irregular schedules may require modified protocols

ideal_candidates: Those wishing to reduce or eliminate sleep medications
screening_required: Rule out sleep apnea or restless legs syndrome

practitioner: Licensed psychologist, psychiatrist, or behavioral sleep medicine specialist trained in CBT-I

studies: Morin CM, Bootzin RR, Buysse DJ, Edinger JD, Espie CA, Lichstein KL. (2006). Psychological and behavioral treatment of insomnia: an update of recent evidence.
Trauer JM, Qian MY, Doyle JS, Rajaratnam SM, Cunnington D. (2015). Cognitive behavioral therapy for chronic insomnia: A meta-analysis.
Edinger JD, Means MK. (2005). Cognitive–behavioral therapy for primary insomnia.
sections.limitations: Requires high patient motivation and adherence; some individuals may struggle with sleep restriction therapy initially.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under behavioral sleep medicine or psychotherapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective compared to chronic use of sleep medications, with durable long-term effects

concurrent_therapies: CBT for comorbid depression or anxiety

sections.older-adults: Particularly effective and safe for older adults where sedative-hypnotics are high-risk.
sections.medical-comorbidities: Adaptable for patients with chronic pain, cardiovascular disease, or cancer-related insomnia.
sections.digital-delivery: Validated digital CBT-I programs expand access for underserved populations.

items: CBT-I is recommended as first-line therapy for insomnia by AASM and NIH.
Unlike sleep medications, benefits persist long after treatment ends.
Digital CBT-I platforms (e.g., Sleepio, SHUTi) have strong evidence for efficacy.
